chapter_title: Great Circles, Rhumb Lines & Directions on the Earth

questions.question: What is the change of latitude between the following positions:-

subQuestions.subQuestionText: d. 71°20'N to 86°45'N over the North Pole.

questions.question: What is the difference in nautical miles and in kilometres from position A (41°25'N) to position B (79°30'N)? Both are on the same meridian.
What is the change of longitude between the following positions:-
Give the direction and change of latitude and longitude from X to Y in each case:
Give the shortest distance in nautical miles and kilometres between the following positions:
An aircraft is to fly from position 72°00'N 002°30'E to position 72°00'N 177°30'W on the shortest possible route.

subQuestions.subQuestionText: a. Give the initial (True) track direction
b. Will the track direction remain the same for the whole flight?
c. Give a reason for the answer given in b above.
subQuestions.solution: Route over the North Pole, initial track True North, then once over the Pole, True South.

questions.question: You are at position A at 54°20'N 002°30'W Given a ch.lat of 16°20'N and a ch.long of 20°30'W to B, what is the position of B?
You are at position C at 36°47'S 179°21'E. Given a ch.lat of 46°47'N and a ch.long of 20°30'E to D, what is the position of D?
What is the position of the Rhumb Line between 2 points relative to the Great Circle between the same points if the points are:

subQuestions.solution: Nearer the Equator (South of the Great Circle)
Nearer the Equator (North of the Great Circle)

questions.question: Any Meridian Line is a:
options: Rhumb Line and a semi Great Circle
questions.solution: Rhumb Line and a semi Great Circle

questions.question: A Rhumb Line cuts all meridians at the same angle. This gives:
options: The shortest distance between two points.
A line which could never be a Great Circle track
